main event: On July 30, 1951, a ground-visual observation of an unidentified object was reported at Selfridge Air Force Base, Michigan. The object was observed at a high altitude with no observed meteors or similar activity at that time. Technical representatives attributed the sighting to certain set of electronic and atmospheric conditions, concluding it as Anomalous Propagation and possibly caused by a balloon.
interesting points: The observer, 1st Lt. Robert K. Hall, reported the sighting at Selfridge Air Force Base, Michigan.
The object was observed at a speed of approximately 30,000 to an estimated 28,000 miles per hour with no observed meteors or similar activity at that time.
The observation lasted for 15 minutes, and no photographs were available.
The report mentioned that technical representatives attributed the sighting to certain electronic and atmospheric conditions, concluding it as Anomalous Propagation and possibly caused by a balloon.
The Air Intelligence Information Report indicated that the object detected gained in altitude from 13,142 to 22,000 feet, and further investigation was recommended.
witnesses: 1st Lt. Robert K. Hall, 17th of Latell Air Division, Office of the Air Adjutant General
